conversation.content: [startled] I saw your name on the residency paperwork when I was checking the green room schedule, and I thought it had to be someone else with the same name.
Well, it's not exactly a common name, so I guess we both know this isn't a coincidence anymore. [clears throat]
Fifteen years, Dad. Fifteen years of nothing, and now you're just here, sleeping in the quarters above where I've worked for the past three seasons.
[quietly] I didn't know you worked here when I applied for the residency, I swear, but when I saw your name on the crew list, I couldn't just leave.
You couldn't leave? That's rich, considering how good you were at it the first time around when Mom got sick.
I know how it looked, but there were things happening then that you didn't understand, things I'm still not proud of. [pause]
[voice cracking] I was twelve years old, trying to figure out how to work her oxygen machine while you were god knows where doing god knows what.
Prison. I was in prison for eighteen months, and your mother made me promise never to tell you because she thought you'd be better off not knowing.
[stunned] What? Mom said you were touring with that production company in Europe, that you chose the work over us.
She was protecting you from the truth about why I got arrested, about the debts I'd accumulated trying to pay for her experimental treatments. [voice breaking]
So you're telling me everything I believed about why you left, everything that shaped who I became, was based on a lie?
[desperately] Not a lie, a choice your mother made out of love, though I see now how much damage it did to both of us.
The medical bills, the ones that kept appearing even after she died, those were from treatments you arranged? We thought they were billing errors.
I kept paying what I could from inside, then after, working under the table jobs because my record made it impossible to get legitimate work. [exhales shakily]
[softer] The theater board doesn't know about your record, do they? That's why you're using Mom's maiden name on the residency application.
They'd cancel my residency immediately if they knew, but I had to take the chance when I heard you might be here. [sighs]
I could report you right now, get you thrown out, and honestly part of me wants to after everything we went through thinking you abandoned us.
[bravely] Then do it. I'd understand completely, but just know that every single day for fifteen years, I've regretted not fighting harder to tell you the truth.
[voice trembling] I don't know what to do with this, with you being here, with everything being different than what I thought.
Just think about it.

scenario: A front of house engineer discovers that the new temporary resident in the artist quarters above the theater is their estranged father who abandoned them fifteen years ago.
